sub_topic: Prove that the intersection of two sets is a subset of each of the sets.
message_1: Let set A = {1, 2, 3, 4} and set B = {2, 3, 5}, find the intersection of set A and set B and prove that it is a subset of each of the sets.
message_2:
To find the intersection of set A and set B, we look for the elements that are common to both sets. In this case, the elements 2 and 3 are present in both set A and set B. Therefore, the intersection of set A and set B is:

Intersection(A, B) = {2, 3}

Now, we need to prove that this intersection is a subset of each of the sets A and B. A subset is a set whose elements are all members of another set. In other words, if all elements of the intersection are also elements of set A and set B, then the intersection is a subset of both sets.

For set A, we can see that both elements 2 and 3 are members of set A:

2 ∈ A and 3 ∈ A

For set B, we can also see that both elements 2 and 3 are members of set B:

2 ∈ B and 3 ∈ B

Since all elements of the intersection are members of both sets A and B, we can conclude that the intersection is a subset of each of the sets:

Intersection(A, B) ⊆ A and Intersection(A, B) ⊆ B
